name: Palace Hotel Port Townsend

reviews.text: Old fashion hotel in central location to shops and restaurants. Rooms are furnished with an antique flare and some bathrooms have claw feet tubs. Rooms slightly over-priced compared to nice bed and breakfasts in the area.
reviews.title: Great Location and Ambiance

reviews.text: The coffee shop at the back is excellent beyond belief - for breakfast or lunch.
reviews.title: overpriced and overrated
Comfortable bed & history lesson
reviews.text: Rooms either have a kitchen or micro and fridge. Unfortunately the kitchens are somewhat modern and do not suit the style of hotel or rooms. The ruined the old feel with the cabinets that don't match.
No internet but certainly a neat experience.
reviews.title: Palace is the Place to Stay
Grand Old Girl Lives Up to Her Name
reviews.text: We stayed at the Palace hotel based on their website and the rave reviews on Trip Advisor. I spoke with the receptionist when I booked the room and decided on one of the most expensive rooms, Miss Pearl. We were terribly disappointed when we walked into what was a tired, worn out room with filthy windows, a bed like cement and pillows which should have been disposed of years ago. They had a screen propped in the lower quarter of the window and a large fan on a stand to cool the room (how charming)...it sounded like a jet engine. We took a look at several of the other rooms whos doors were standing open and inquired at the desk if any of them were available (especially since none were all to special, but at least they were on a lower floor so we wouldn't have to haul baggage up all the flights to the top floor). The room we were really interested in we were told was taken but were offered a lesser room at $20 more than we were quoted for the room we wanted. We decided that even though it wasn't wonderful by any means at least it was bearable and we were committed to stay there (although we would have loved to have changed hotels altogether).

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Wow. The Palace has really been gettlng slammed by reviewers lately.
reviews.title: No Phones and Walking up steps--No Problem

reviews.text: Port Townsend is a fabulous city. It's artsy and hip but still has that small-town vibe, unlike many other small towns that have the countryfide, arts and crafts atmosphere. Staying at the Palace Hotel enhanced our PT experience.
reviews.title: Didn't Even get the chance to stay here!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: When you walk up the steps to your room, it feels like it should--an old hotel. Not some gutted out, sterilized chain hotel with shiney new fixutures. The original brick walls and Victorian decor adds to the sophistication and charm of the place. Our rooms were very clean and its high ceilings made it spacious and airy. The tall windows enabled natural light to radiate throughout the space.
reviews.title: Will never go back
If you HAVE to do Victorian....
reviews.text: The street noise didn't bother us. We live in the city of Seattle so we're used to loud cars and people (not that it's that noisy in PT) among other things. We also didn't mind walking up the steps to our room. We didn't care about not having a phone in our room. We never felt like we were roughing it or deprived of any modern amenities.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Palace's central location in the town center also makes it perfect for exploring all of PT's botique shops, trendy restaurants, art studios, and historic movie theater.
reviews.title: Fun but a bit uncomfortable - not romatic

likes.disliked: — Bed, location of room in the hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Touted as historic, but frankly just old. Old rickity furniture in the room and the lobbies, retrofitted problematic metal windows installed right over original wood frames (with removeable screens that were torn), uncomfortable bed and bed linens, a decor mix of dusty old victorian and 1980's frilly country. And, a walk up three flights of stairs to get to our room which would have been fine if the room had been worth the hike. The hotel location was great... right on the main street. Very convenient. And the staff was gentle and kind. But the place needs serious TLC by people who understand design rennovation.
reviews.title: Sorry... Not so great.

reviews.text: We stayed in the "Miss Lily" the night after a long hike. Four kids my husband, myself and my dog, were warmly welcomed. They had assured us the "Miss Lily" was roomy enough for all, and it was, with an extra rollaway bed. This is actually a huge space. I have never slept so well in a hotel room.
reviews.title: Beautiful hotel, Lovely room, great price

likes.liked: — Big room, beautiful decor,allowed the dog

reviews.text: They had a "doggy bag" for my dog which consisted of a towel, a sheet and dog dishes to use during the stay. The extra cost per night for a dog is $10, very reasonable. We couldn't believe how nice the hotel was for the price. We loved the location, right in town close to restaurants and shops. Close to the ferry.
reviews.title: Wonderful experience

likes.disliked: — No elevators and it's somewhat noisy as it's in

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My sister and I stayed at the Palace for two nights. The hotel is clean, safe, and seriously charming. There are a variety of lovely rooms - old-fashioned quilted bedspreads, lace curtains, unique bathrooms. We had a huge suite (Miss Lily) - queen bed in the separate bedroom, double futon bed (comfortable) in the LR. There was a small, but complete, kitchen. The rooms must have had 15 - 20 foot ceilings - bright, airy, comfortable. The staff were helpful and knowlegeable. The hotel was right in the centre of old town on Water Street (the main street in the downtown core). It was minutes from just about any service. There was some noise from the street, but ear plugs work. And, there are plenty of stairs and no elevators. That's 30 plus stairs to the second floor and another 25 or so to the third floor. Staff will assist with luggage. I looked upon climbing the stairs as my personal physical fitness regime. I highly recommend this hotel...
reviews.title: Very pleasant little old hotel; noisy neighbors

likes.disliked: — Noisy Tyler Street Coffee Shop baker

reviews.title: Bed was as hard as a rock
reviews.text: Port Townsend is an attractive little community which we enjoy visiting when in the northwest. The Palace Hotel is a quaint old hotel in the old downtown portion the the town with convenient access to shopping and dining. Our small room was at the rear of the building which we thought would be quieter than one at the front which faces the main street. Boy were we wrong! At 5:15a.m. a loud boom-boom, thumpity-thumpity music began vibrating the floorboards in our room awakening my wife and me. By 5:30 when it hadn't stopped, I dressed and went to investigate (there are no phones in the room by which to contact the manager). I could not find the source after walking around our second floor, or up on the third floor, so I went down to the first level and still couldn't find the source. I went outside and walked around the entire block but without luck in locating the source. Upon my return to the hotel, I found the "after hours" phone in the hall and used it to awaken the manager and lodge a complaint. He came down the stairs, looking somewhat disheveled (as one would expect at that hour in the otherwise sleeply town) and said the sound was probably coming from the kitchen of the Tyler Street Coffee Shop which is located directly below our room and he would call there and check it out. Seems he was right; the baker usually starts around 5:00 and apparently on this day liked to have some loud music (to help settle the muffins?) while working. The music level did seem to decrease after the manager called... maybe from 125db down to 100db or so! Later my wife went down to the offending bakery/coffee shop for a cup of coffee which turned out to not be as good as the cup I made in the room. So, two lessons learned: don't take a room at the rear of the Palace Hotel and don't get a cup of coffee from the Tyler Street Coffee Shop. A little later we had an excellent breakfast at the Salal Restaurant which is a couple of blocks down the street from the hotel.

The Palace Hotel was great! My sister and I stayed for two nights in the last part of October. The Palace was clean, and in good condition. We got the room we asked for and it was better than the pictures. I found this hotel through their web site, which has pictures of all the rooms and lists specials and amenities.
reviews.title: Awsom Place!
Upgrades make this stay even better
reviews.text: The only thing wrong with this hotel is that some of the web sites information is not correct.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: If you like history or antiques you’ll love the Palace!
reviews.title: Great Hotel

reviews.text: I stayed in this Hotel a few years ago and really enjoyed it but am pleased that when I returned there are noticeable upgrades. This Victorian Hotel is in a great location for shopping and I enjoyed an evening gallery walk during our stay. Rooms are clean and new linens are a nice upgrade. Loved my morning breakfast tray..
reviews.title: Great atmosphere but noisy

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The front desk was awesome. A personal Touch calling a restaurant for me to make sure they were still serving lunch. Recommending best dessert places etc. The Evening front desk help made such a difference in our stay. This Gal should teach a course on hospitality.
reviews.title: Unique and Sparkling Clean

likes.disliked: — Lack of Water pressure and spotty internet service

description: This beautifully restored Victorian hotel is in the heart of historic Port Townsend. A former bordello with most rooms named after former working girls including Madame Maries suite and Miss Kittys room, this Magnuson Hotels affiliate is located one block from the ferry dock in the center of many fine art galleries, restaurants, theaters, antique stores, and unique gift shops.
